details.description: Tax credit overpayments - dispute form TC846, repaying tax credits, repayment methods (including Direct Debits), payment helpline

parts.title: Overpayments
parts.body:
You have to repay any tax credits you’re not entitled to. Overpayments happen if:

  • you don’t report a change in your circumstance to the Tax Credit Office
  • you make a mistake on your claim form

The Tax Credit Office will tell you what you owe and how to repay it. Overpayments can be repaid:

  • by reducing your tax credits
  • through your tax code - if you owe less than £3,000
  • as a lump sum

If you owe less than £3,000

HM Revenue & Customs can change your PAYE tax code to collect your overpayment. You’ll pay back what you owe by paying more tax in the next tax year (6 April).

This only happens if:

  • your overpayment is less than £3,000
  • you work for an employer, or get a UK-based pension
  • you haven’t contacted the Tax Credit Office about repaying the overpayment

Making extra payments

If you want to make extra payments to clear the debt more quickly - call the Tax Credit Payment Helpline.

Tax Credit Payment Helpline

0845 302 1429

parts.title: Dispute form TC846
parts.body:
If you’re asked to repay an overpayment of tax credits you can dispute the overpayment.

You don’t have to repay any money until you get a decision about the dispute.

How to dispute the overpayment

Send a dispute form to the Tax Credit Office.

Download ‘Form TC846, Dispute a tax credit overpayment decision’ (PDF, 26KB)

Overpayment Disputes Team
Tax Credit Office
Preston
PR1 4AT

What happens next

You’ll get a letter telling you:

  • if you have to repay the tax credits
  • how much you have to repay
  • the reasons for the decision

If you don’t agree with the decision

You can:

  • send them new information - they’ll stop recovering the overpayment
  • ask them to review the information you sent - they won’t stop recovering the overpayment

If you haven’t got any new information and you’re still unhappy, contact an organisation like Citizens Advice.

parts.title: Repay your tax credits
parts.body:
It’s your responsibility to make sure payments reach HMRC on time. Check your bank’s transaction limits and processing times.

Usually, you must repay what you owe within 30 days of the ‘notice to pay’ - call the helpline if this is a problem, they may let you pay in instalments.

Payment Helpline
0845 302 1429

Direct Debit

Call the helpline to set up a Direct Debit. You can also set it up via your HMRC online account if you already have an one (eg you do your Self Assessment tax returns online).

You need your tax credit reference number and bank details. It takes up to 5 working days to set up and payments appear on your statements as ‘HMRC NDDS’.

Online and telephone banking

Use your tax credit reference number as the payment reference and the bank details below.

Sort code Account number Account name
08 32 10 12001039 HMRC Cumbernauld

Overseas accounts

If you’re paying from an overseas account use the details as below. You can pay in sterling or another currency.

Account name IBAN BIC
HMRC Cumbernauld GB74CITI08321012001039 CITIGB2L

If asked for the IBAN, you must also give the BIC.

HMRC’s bank address is: Citi, Citigroup Centre, Canada Square, Canary Wharf, London E14 5LB.

Your bank or building society

Use your payslip to pay at your own bank by cash or cheque made payable to ‘HM Revenue & Customs only’ followed by your tax credit reference number. Allow 3 working days for payments to reach HMRC.

Post Office

You must use your payslip. You can pay by debit card, cash or cheque made payable to ‘Post Office Ltd’. Allow 3 working days for payments to reach HMRC.

Post

Include your payslip and cheque made payable to ‘HM Revenue & Customs only’ followed by your payslip reference number. Allow 3 working days for payments to reach HMRC.

HM Revenue & Customs
Bradford
BD98 1YY

Don’t fold your payslip or cheque or fasten them together. If you want a receipt, include a note asking for one. You can only send a postdated cheque if you have HMRC’s permission.

If you don’t have a payslip

If you don’t have a payslip, include:

  • your contact details
  • your tax credit number
  • how much you’re paying
  • period you’re paying for
